publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-1718 Robin Harper: Generic Drugs for Developing Countries—That the Parliament notes with concern the legal challenge which GlaxoSmithKline and other pharmaceutical companies have brought against the South African 1997 Medicines and Related Substances Control Amendment Act which was introduced by the South African Government, under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, to improve access to affordable medicines for the people of South Africa, and calls upon these companies to withdraw immediately from the legal action and undertake not to prevent governments of developing countries from adopting measures to make vital medicines more affordable.
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Linda Fabiani*
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Tommy Sheridan*

S1M-1718 Robin Harper: Generic Drugs for Developing Countries—That the Parliament notes with concern the legal challenge which GlaxoSmithKline and other pharmaceutical companies have brought against the South African 1997 Medicines and Related Substances Control Amendment Act which was introduced by the South African Government, under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, to improve access to affordable medicines for the people of South Africa, and calls upon these companies to withdraw immediately from the legal action and undertake not to prevent governments of developing countries from adopting measures to make vital medicines more affordable. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Tommy Sheridan
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Shona Robison*
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Ms Sandra White*
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Mr Gil Paterson*, Mr Lloyd Quinan*, Cathy Peattie*

S1M-1718 Robin Harper: Generic Drugs for Developing Countries—That the Parliament notes with concern the legal challenge which GlaxoSmithKline and other pharmaceutical companies have brought against the South African 1997 Medicines and Related Substances Control Amendment Act which was introduced by the South African Government, under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, to improve access to affordable medicines for the people of South Africa, and calls upon these companies to withdraw immediately from the legal action and undertake not to prevent governments of developing countries from adopting measures to make vital medicines more affordable. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Tommy Sheridan, Shona Robison, Ms Sandra White, Mr Gil Paterson, Mr Lloyd Quinan, Cathy Peattie
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Kay Ullrich*
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Donald Gorrie*, Mrs Margaret Ewing*, Andrew Wilson*, Elaine Smith*

S1M-1718 Robin Harper: Generic Drugs for Developing Countries—That the Parliament notes with concern the legal challenge which GlaxoSmithKline and other pharmaceutical companies have brought against the South African 1997 Medicines and Related Substances Control Amendment Act which was introduced by the South African Government, under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, to improve access to affordable medicines for the people of South Africa, and calls upon these companies to withdraw immediately from the legal action and undertake not to prevent governments of developing countries from adopting measures to make vital medicines more affordable. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Tommy Sheridan, Shona Robison, Ms Sandra White, Mr Gil Paterson, Mr Lloyd Quinan, Cathy Peattie, Kay Ullrich, Donald Gorrie, Mrs Margaret Ewing, Andrew Wilson, Elaine Smith
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Ms Margo MacDonald*, Mr Keith Raffan*
S1M-1718 Generic Drugs for Developing Countries (lodged on 5 March 2001) Tricia Marwick*

S1M-1718 Robin Harper: Generic Drugs for Developing Countries—That the Parliament notes with concern the legal challenge which GlaxoSmithKline and other pharmaceutical companies have brought against the South African 1997 Medicines and Related Substances Control Amendment Act which was introduced by the South African Government, under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, to improve access to affordable medicines for the people of South Africa, and calls upon these companies to withdraw immediately from the legal action and undertake not to prevent governments of developing countries from adopting measures to make vital medicines more affordable. Supported by: Linda Fabiani, Tommy Sheridan, Shona Robison, Ms Sandra White, Mr Gil Paterson, Mr Lloyd Quinan, Cathy Peattie, Kay Ullrich, Donald Gorrie, Mrs Margaret Ewing, Andrew Wilson, Elaine Smith, Ms Margo MacDonald, Mr Keith Raffan, Tricia Marwick
